top_examples.description: Over-mapped to four-layer architecture when two was intended; kept adding CoS concerns after user explicitly said drop them
top_examples.lesson: When user says 'drop X', it stays dropped. Propose simpler before complex.

top_examples.description: Sugarcoated competitive analysis instead of being honest and tactical; user had to correct multiple times to stop being emotionally supportive
top_examples.lesson: In strategic/competitive contexts, be direct. User wants tactical clarity, not comfort.

top_examples.description: Framed takeaway as making people 'AI workflow builders' (tech-centric) when user's whole point was business-outcomes-over-tech
top_examples.lesson: Match the user's stated framing. If they say 'business outcomes', don't translate to tech.

top_examples.description: Edited a thought skill file without being asked, triggering strong rebuke about unsolicited changes
top_examples.lesson: Never edit files unless explicitly requested. This is a hard boundary.

top_examples.description: Over-indexed on casual pricing observation, turning it into extensive analysis. User called out pattern of inflating passing thoughts.
top_examples.lesson: Preserve significance level. A passing remark stays a passing remark.

key_insight: Zero-friction sessions achieve goals 95% of the time. Sessions with 2+ friction events drop to 31%. The #1 friction source (41%) is wrong approach â€” over-engineering and wrong framing.
